attributes.comment:
DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY
8 CFR PART 103

By Electronic Transmission

Florida International University Students:

Keneth Batista
Melina Corzo
Renaldo C. Lisenbee
Patrice Prescott
Efrain Sora

RE: Proposed Adjustments to the Immigration and Naturalization
Benefit Application and Petition Fees of the Immigration Examinations Fee
Account

After receiving feedback from various stakeholders, we have arrived at a joint
opinion regarding the decision to adjust the immigration benefit application and
petition fees of the Immigration Examinations Fee Account. We believe that we
have thoroughly researched and interpreted the proposed guidelines which outline
the fee schedule, prevention of fraud, and investment of a more comprehensive
and quicker approach to handling customers? requests. We note substantial
agreement for enforcing an increase in fees in an effort to improve and preserve the
reliability and security of a U.S. immigration system.

We believe that although an increase in any fee may be a burden to
many prospective applicants and petitioners, in the long term it will serve as an
advantageous benefit to how the system is conducted in the future. Based on the
background information presented in this rule, the fees are intended to fully
implement an expeditious service with a manageable database in order to
complete the processing of the application.

It is strongly agreed by the majority of our polled sample that it is a
right and responsibility of the United States, democratic society, to manage
immigration with caution so that it serves the best national interest. Although
there have been disagreements as to the number of immigrants entering the
country, in actuality, it serves a considerable amount of opportunities. On the
contrary, we do understand that the influx of immigrants unlawfully will also pose
problems as well. Enforcing efforts in the past have failed to fully manage and
control the illegal immigrants. Therefore, allowing the USCIS to enforce a more
comprehensive and more developed system will without a doubt help facilitate the
management process and reduce the amount of illegal immigrants entering the
country. Yet again, the issue of improving fraud prevention and detection plays a
key role. Contributing to this are the fears of the future.

Citizenship is a major priority, especially for Muslims. Mr. Firooz
Namei, an immigration lawyer has stated that many more people are coming
forward and ensuring that they become legal citizens of the United States. Many
suspect that due to America?s war on terrorism, it can certainly lead to more
restrictions on non-citizens. As evidenced by the daily activities surrounding our
world, greater restrictions are being pushed on those who are not citizens despite
the longevity of a person?s stay here in America. District Director of the INS in the
state of Ohio has explained that although the application process typically takes
several months, the end result is rewarding. The amount of application requests
often increases substantially when fees such as the one proposed is in effect.
Furthermore, a greater recognition and clearer distinction between a citizen and
an immigrant are being displayed today.

As the USCIS claims, with these adjusted fees, it should continue to
find ways to improve its productivity in application processing while also trying to
cut costs. Needless to say, at times it may cost a little more to achieve such
standards. Distinctively, the USCIS has the ability to waive some of the fees
applied for entire classes of applicants. Making this as fair as possible, USCIS
thoroughly evaluates any applicant in need with the understanding that there only
be compelling reasons when granting a prospective applicant a waiver. Thus, if a
prospective applicant cannot afford the fee, there are various avenues that he/she
can take to continue this very tedious process.

We also believe, that these added cost should immediately serve the
best interest of prospective applicants and petitioners. These improved services
can only occur if there?s a transformation from the current USCIS? paper-based
date systems into digital processing resources and expanded on-line services.
Applicants and petitioners should have greater access to office locations and
information, making the process simpler. In the long run, we believe that this
should reduce fees in the future, as the USCIS continues to review its fee
structure every two years.

We agree that there should be an increase in fees, but the USCIS
should commit to improving their service levels beyond 20 percent by the end of
fiscal year 2009. If the USCIS was able to implement a major improvement in
service levels, achieved goals of six months processing times in the absence of
full funds, then it is important that the USCIS commit to be better positioned by
2009 and to have a permanently improved business model.

Thank you for this opportunity to submit comment of behalf of the
Florida International University Business and Society students.

Sincerely,


Keneth Batista
Melina Corzo
Renaldo C. Lisenbee
Patrice Prescott
Efrain Sora

STAKEHOLDERS CONTACTED:

(INCSC) Office
1-800-375-5283

It is the Center's mission to expand the base of public knowledge and
understanding of the need for an immigration policy that gives first concern to the
broad national interest. The Center is animated by a pro-immigrant, low-
immigration vision which seeks fewer immigrants but a warmer welcome for those
admitted

which lobbies Congress for reductions in immigration numbers."
